Sarah Stewart likes to think about what happens when planets collide she uses to actual canon to simulate those massive impact here's one firing in her lab at UC Davis

She uses to actual canon stimulate those massive impact here's one firing in her lab at UC Davis
Three two
Her work earned her a spot in this year's class of MacArthur fellows many let's call it the genius grant for years experts have thought the earth's moon formed after a large collusion knocked off a bunch of rock Stewart told me her research suggests a different story
During planet formation when two bodies collide there's so much energy released that most of these bodies are vaporized that means that a rocky planet like earth is mostly rock vapor
What does rocket vapor and and what does it have to do with our moon
Rock paper is taking the rocks that we stand on end heating it up to the point where it becomes the gas
And when that occurs the earth becomes much larger because vapor is much less dense ... and it extends out into this enormous object hundreds of times larger than the earth today and we proposed that our moon grows within the rock vapor of the earth after a giant impact
Came from the earth
The moon grows within the rock vapor of the earth and that gives the moon the same chemistry at the earth
How much of a revelation was that I mean how different was that from what scientists used to think about where the moon came from
It was hard to imagine that things could be so different and it was a mental roadblock to realize that giant impacts transformed a planet into an entirely new type of object and that could explain one of the biggest mysteries in the solar system
Did you have to overcome some mental road blocks of your own given what you would have been taught coming through academia
Absolutely and this is when we had a bona fide eureka moment to my graduate student and I are sitting in front of a computer looking at the calculation that we had done and realizing that owns the assumptions are actually violated
By what we're looking at I think in any field there's a degree to which people have to be taught to trust themselves and maybe women even more than men are taught not to trust themselves was it difficult for you to have confidence that yeah well I've demonstrated here actually is real
Scientists are terrified of being wrong [laughter] so of course I didn't want to put something out there that was really a crazy idea and so we did have to convince ourselves first
How long did that take you to convince yourself
Well [laughter] from the eureka moment to the published paper with for years so I think we had a lot of internal debates
A amongst the co authors and a lot of debates at conferences on the origin of the men
So do you expect if ten years from now I pick up a high school textbook it's going to have the results of your research there in the chapter on how earth's moon was formed
[noise] I certainly hope so I Am very excited about this idea and I hope that it leads to test where we can prove whether or not the moon actually formed in the earth vapor
Why are these kinds of questions relevant to ordinary people who are not scientists why does it matter where the moon came from for example
The creation of the men was the last major event in the creation of the earth and it was such a violent act it left the earth and the state very different from today
Understanding how earth became the habitable planet that it is is directly linked to the final event and creation
You're saying it's part of our story absolutely how did you get interested in planetary collisions
I wanted to study planet formation and in the process I learned that collisions were the major physical prowess
... I wanted to study planet formation and in the process I learned that collisions were the major physical process to grow planets and I had the opportunity to study them in the lab and I've been doing it ever since
We've kind of kid who was always going in the backyard staring at the stars
[noise] I had my nose in books imagining space travel I very much enjoyed science fiction
So for you is studying climate to fall back to actually traveling through space
[laughter] I might be too terrified to actually go up in space [laughter] exploration and our imagination and through the laws of physics has been exciting enough for me [noise]
Search Stewart is a planetary scientist at the University of California Davis and two days she was named to the new class of MacArthur fellows congratulations and thanks for talking with us thank you
